mimes.text/plain: s and how to use it to create your custom learning tasks without the data block interface
ve already seen a learning task in action:
The learning task abstraction powers FastAI
level interface allowing you to make training models for a task simple
is a particularly convenient and composable interface for creating learning tasks and should be preferred for most use cases
However, to get a look behind the scenes, in this tutorial we
level learning task interface to implement our own version of an image classification learning task
re encouraged to follow along in a REPL or notebook
This tutorial can also serve as a template for implementing a custom learning task for your own project
A learning task describes how we need to process data so we can train a model for some task
In our case, the task we want to solve is to classify an image
The task defines what kind of data we need, here pairs of images and class labels
t enough to train a model since we can
t just throw an image in any format into a model and get a class out
Almost always the input data needs to be processed in some way before it is input to a model (we call this
) and the same goes for the model outputs (we call this
s say we have an image and a trained model
How do we make a prediction? First we encode the image, run it through the model, and then decode the output
Similarly, how we can use a pair of image and class to train a model? We encode both, run the encoded input through the model and then compare the output with the encoded class using a
The result tells us how we
ll need to update the weights of the model to improve its performance
In essence, the learning task interface allows us to implement these steps and derive useful functionality from it, like training and evaluating models
ll also cover some optional interfaces that allow us to define other parts of a deep learning project
that we can test our code on as we go
s always a good idea to interactively test your code
ll be implementing a task for image classification, the observations in our data container will of course have to be pairs of images and classes
ll use one of the many image classification datasets available from the fastai dataset repository
ll use ImageNette, but you can use any of the datasets listed in
The way the interface is built allows you to easily swap out the dataset you
ll also collect the unique class names:
The first thing we need to do is to create a
should contain all the configuration needed for encoding and decoding the data
ll keep it simple here and include a list of the classes and the image dimensions input to the model
Now we can create an instance of it, though of course it can
There are 3 tasks we need to define before we can use our learning task to train models and make predictions:
which encodes an image and a class
will encode an image so it can be input to a model
decodes a model output into a class label
Note: These functions always operate on
images and classes, even if we want to pass batches to the model later on
s not the focus of this tutorial, let
s give a quick recap of how the data is encoded and decoded for image classification
Images are cropped to a common size so they can be batched, converted to a 3D array with dimensions (height, width, color channels) and normalized
hot vectors, teaching the model to predict a confidence distribution over all classes
hot vector, we can simply find the index with the highest value and look up the class label
Each of the tasks also takes a
argument which allows it to behave differently during training, validation and inference
ll make use of that to choose a different image crop for each situation
ll use a random crop for augmentation, while during validation a center crop will ensure that any metrics we track are the same every epoch

comparing a batch of model outputs and encoded targets
: from a backbone, construct a model suitable for the task
s start with the loss function
We want to compare two one
hot encoded categorical variables, for which categorical cross entropy is the most commonly used loss function
re getting a convolutional feature extractor passed in as a backbone so its output will be of size (height, width, channels, batch size)
can be used to calculate the output size of arbitrary models without having to evaluate the model
ll use it to check the number of output channels of the backbone
Then we add a global pooling layer and some dense layers on top to get a classification output
